column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=Classic Maya carved wooden lintel looted from the site of El Zotz , Guatemala , in the late 1960s and repatriated from the collection of the Denver Art Museum in 1998 .
#Text=El Zotz Lintel 1 is a carved wooden doorway lintel composed of five sopadilla wood planks forming a panel that is 180 cm by 74 cm .
#Text=It is stylistically dated to between 550 and 650 AD and depicts a standing male figure who is carrying a diagonal ceremonial bar and holding an upright decorated staff .
#Text=The lintel would have been an important structural element of Structure M7-1 , a 22.5-metre-high pyramid in the East Group of the Classic Maya site of El Zotz .
#Text=The lintel would have spanned a doorway making it a decorative element that would have helped to bear the weight of the stone building .
#Text=The El Zotz lintel was removed from Temple 1 by looters who significantly damaged the piece by hacking away the back of it with a hatchet to reduce its weight .
#Text=It was then trafficked into the United States .
#Text=The lintel surfaced in the gallery of New York-based dealer Edward Merrin sometime in the early 1970s .
#Text=According to information collected by New York Times reporter William Grimes , Merrin then sold the piece to the law firm of Berry & Stark Associates which was based in Denver Colorado .
#Text=In 1973 the firm donated the lintel to the Denver Art Museum .
#Text=Merrin told Grimes that he did not remember selling the lintel but did not rule out that he did .
#Text=This seems unusual , since preserved Maya carved wooden lintels are extremely rare and memorable : El Zotz Lintel 1 is one of only about five known examples of this type artefact .

#Text=Working from the wood fragments that he recorded in situ in 1978 , Ian Graham was able to positively link the lintel held by the Denver Art Museum to the lintel missing from Temple 1 at El Zotz .

#Text=Based on this connection and a review of their own records regarding the acquisition of the piece , the Denver Art Museum voluntarily repatriated the lintel to Guatemala in 1998 with museum representatives stating that ‘ returning it was simply the right thing to do ’ .
#Text=The piece is now in the Museo Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología in Guatemala City .
#Text=There is some debate about when exactly the lintel was looted from El Zotz .
#Text=Juan Pedro Laporte of the Proyecto Nacional Tikal reports that the lintel was likely removed from Temple 1 between 1966 and 1968 .
#Text=Stephen D Houston of the Proyecto Arqueológico El Zotz places the looting of the lintel to 1975 , basing his date on Ian Graham ’ s 1978 observations at the site .
#Text=Laporte ’ s date for the removal appears more plausible in light of the 1973 acquisition of the piece by the Denver Art Museum .
#Text=The inscriptions on the lintel are helpful for understanding the socio-political sphere that El Zotz operated within .

#Text=Epigrapher David Stuart has noted that one of the emblem glyphs ( essentially , glyphs that were used to identify a particular Classic Maya polity ; the ‘ name ’ of the site in a sense ) on the El Zotz lintel also serve to identify a particular dynasty at the site of Yaxchilán in Chiapas , Mexico .

#Text=This may be a coincidence , but it is possible that either the ruling dynasty of Yaxchilán had its origins at El Zotz or that the glyph may indicate that El Zotz was a component of a wider zone that was identified by this emblem .
#Text=This information would not be known if the provenience of the lintel had not been established .
#Text=It is unclear what information has been lost from inscriptions that may have been erased from the portion of the piece that was damaged during the looting event .
